PREAMBLE.p: First introduced as the Constitution of the Federation of Malaya on Merdeka Day: 16th September 1963
Subsequently introduced as the Constitution of Malaysia on Malaysia Day: 31st August 1957

b.PARTTITLE: THE STATES, RELIGION AND LAW OF THE FEDERATION

b.ST: Name, States and territories of the Federation.

SECTION.p: (1) The Federation shall be known, in Malay and in English, by the name Malaysia.
(2) The States of the Federation shall be Johore, Kedah, Kelantan, Malacca, Negeri Sembilan, Pahang, Penang, Perak, Perlis, Sabah, Sarawak, Selangor and Terengganu.
(3) Subject to Clause (4), the territories of each of the States mentioned in Clause (2) are the territories comprised therein immediately before Malaysia Day.

(4) The territory of the State of Selangor shall exclude the Federal Territory of Kuala Lumpur established under the Constitution (Amendment) (No. 2) Act 1973 [Act A206] and the Federal Territory of Putrajaya established under the Constitution (Amendment) Act 2001 [Act A1095] and the territory of the State of Sabah shall exclude the Federal Territory of Labuan established under the Constitution (Amendment) (No. 2) Act 1984 [Act A585], and all such Federal Territories shall be territories of the Federation.

p.i: The original Article as it stood on Merdeka Day read as follows:
"1. (1) The Federation shall be known by the name of Persekutuan Tanah Melayu (in English the Federation of Malaya).

(2) The States of the Federation are Johore, Kedah, Kelantan, Negeri Sembilan, Pahang, Perak, Perlis, Selangor and Terengganu (formerly known as the Malay States) and Malacca and Penang (formerly known as the Settlements of Malacca and Penang).
(3) The territories of each of the States mentioned in Clause (2) are the territories of that States immediately before Merdeka Day.".

1. The present Article without Clause (4) was inserted by Act 26/1963, section 4, in force from 16-09-1963 (i.e. when Malaysia was established). Act 59/1966 section 2, in force from 09-08- 1 9 6 5 (i.e. the date Singapore left Malaysia) amended Clause (2) by deleting therefrom paragraph (c) which read as follows:
"(c) the State of Singapore.".

2. The present Clause (2) was substituted by Act A354, section 2, in force from 27-08-1976. This clause before its substitution by Act A354 was amended by Act 26/1963, section 4, in force from 16-09-1963 (i.e. when Malaysia was established) read as follows:
"(2) The States of the Federation shall be-
(a) the States of Malaya, namely, Johore, Kedah, Kelantan, Malacca, Negeri Sembilan, Pahang, Penang, Perak, Perlis, Selangor and Terengganu;
(b) the Borneo States, namely, Sabah and Sarawak; and
(c) the State of Singapore.".

SECTION.blockquote: "(4) The territory of the State of Selangor shall exclude the Federal Territory established under the Constitution (Amendment) (No. 2) Act, 1973.".

Subsection 2(2) of Act A566 also provided w.e.f. 01-02-1974 that-

3. The above Clause was substituted by Act A585, section 11, in force from 16-04-1984.
4. This Clause was again substituted by Act A1095, section 11, in force from 01-02-2001.

NOTE.p: Is Kuala Lumpur part of Malaysia? Please see the Federal Court case of Hen Chean Seng & Anor v. Public Prosecutor [1983] 1 MLRA 40 where the Federal Court answered both questions in the affirmative.

b.ST: Admission of new territories into the Federation.

SECTION.p: Parliament may by law-

blockquote.p: (a) admit other States to the Federation;
(b) alter the boundaries of any State,

SECTION.p: but a law altering the boundaries of a State shall not be passed without the consent of that State (expressed by a law made by the Legislature of that State) and of the Conference of Rulers.

NOTE.p: On the discussion of consent of the Conference of Rulers on State boundaries please see the FCt in Hen Chean Seng & Anor v. Public Prosecutor [1983] 1 MLRA 40. Cf Government of the State Of Kelantan v. Government Of The Federation Of Malaya And Tunku Abdul Rahman Putra Al-Haj [1963] 1 MLRH 160. On the application of Art 2, see the HCt case of James Albanus v. Tan Sri Datuk Seri Panglima Harris Mohd Salleh [2015] 1 MLRH 429.

SECTION.p: (1) Islam is the religion of the Federation; but other religions may be practised in peace and harmony in any part of the Federation.

(2) In every State other than States not having a Ruler the position of the Ruler as the Head of the religion of Islam in his State in the manner and to the extent acknowledged and declared by the Constitution of that State, and, subject to that Constitution, all rights, privileges, prerogatives and powers enjoyed by him as Head of that religion, are unaffected and unimpaired; but in any acts, observances of ceremonies with respect to which the Conference of Rulers has agreed that they should extend to the Federation as a whole each of the other Rulers shall in his capacity of Head of the religion of Islam authorize the Yang di-Pertuan Agong to represent him.

(3) The Constitution of the States of Malacca, Penang, Sabah and Sarawak shall each make provision for conferring on the Yang di-Pertuan Agong the position of Head of the religion of Islam in that State.
(4) Nothing in this Article derogates from any other provision of this Constitution.

(5) Notwithstanding anything in this Constitution the Yang di-Pertuan Agong shall be the head of the religion of Islam in the Federal Territories of Kuala Lumpur, Labuan and Putrajaya; and for this purpose Parliament may be law make provisions for regulating Islamic religious affairs and for constituting a Council to advise the Yang di-Pertuan Agong in matters relating to the religion of Islam.

SECTION.p: (1) This Constitution is the supreme law of the Federation and any law passed after Merdeka Day which is inconsistent with this Constitution shall, to the extent of the inconsistency, be void.
(2) The validity of any law shall not be questioned on the ground that-

blockquote.p: (a) it imposes restrictions on the right mentioned in Article 9(2) but does not relate to the matters mentioned therein; or
(b) it imposes such restrictions as are mentioned in Article 10(2) but those restrictions were not deemed necessary or expedient by Parliament for the purposes mentioned in that Article.

SECTION.p: (3) The validity of any law made by Parliament or the Legislature of any State shall not be questioned on the ground that it makes provision with respect to any matter with respect to which Parliament or, as the case may be, the Legislature of the State has no power to make laws, except in proceedings for a declaration that the law is invalid on that ground or-

blockquote.p: (a) if the law was made by Parliament, in proceedings between the Federation and one or more States;
(b) if the law was made by the Legislature of a State, in proceedings between the Federation and that State.

SECTION.p: (4) Proceedings for a declaration that a law is invalid on the ground mentioned in Clause (3) (not being proceedings falling within paragraph (a) or (b) of the Clause) shall not be commenced without the leave of a judge of the Federal Court; and the Federation shall be entitled to be a party to any such proceedings, and so shall any State that would or might be a party to proceedings brought for the same purpose under paragraph (a) or (b) of the Clause. 19

SECTION.p: (1) No person shall be deprived of his life or personal liberty save in accordance with law.

(2) Where complaint is made to a High Court or any judge thereof that a person is being unlawfully detained the court shall inquire into the complaint and, unless satisfied that the detention is lawful, shall order him to be produced before the court and release him.
(3) Where a person is arrested he shall be informed as soon as may be of the grounds of his arrest and shall be allowed to consult and be defended by a legal practitioner of his choice.

(4) Where a person is arrested and not released he shall without unreasonable delay, and in any case within twenty-four hours (excluding the time of any necessary journey) be produced before a magistrate and shall not be further detained in custody without the magistrate's authority:

Provided that this Clause shall not apply to the arrest or detention of any person under the existing law relating to restricted residence, and all the provisions of this Clause shall be have been an integral part of this Article as from Merdeka Day:

Provided further that in its application to a person, other than a citizen, who is arrested or detained under the law relating to immigration, this Clause shall be read as if there were substituted for the words "without unreasonable delay, and in any case within twenty-four hours (excluding the time of any necessary journey)" the words "within fourteen days":

And provided further that in the case of an arrest for an offence which is triable by a Syariah court, references in this Clause to a magistrate shall be construed as including references to a judge of a Syariah court.
(5) Clauses (3) and (4) do not apply to an enemy alien.

Superintendent Of Prison, Pengkalan Chepa, Kelantan [1967] 1 MLRH 495, Kam Teck Soon v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri Malaysia & Ors And Other Appeals [2002] 2 MLRA 268, FC, Lee Mau Seng v. Minister For Home Affairs, Singapore & Anor [1971] 1 MLRH 428; Chong Kim Loy v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri Malaysia & Anor [1989] 2 MLRH 378; Chia Khin Sze v. Mentri Besar, State Of Selangor [1958] 1 MLRH 90, Jakob Renner (An Infant Suing Through His Father And Next Friend, Gilbert Renner) & Ors v. Scott King, Chairman Of Board Of Directors Of The International School Of Kuala Lumpur & Ors [1999] 4 MLRH 347; Shahkri Bin Hussain v. Menteri Hal Ehwal Dalam Negeri & Penguasa Pusat Pemulihan Serenti [2000] 2 MLRH 574 relating to detention under s 4(1)(b) of the Drug Dependants (Treatment and Rehabilitation) Act 1983).See also Kerajaan Negeri Terengganu v. Petroliam Nasional Bhd & Anor [2002] 6 MLRH 667; Pihak Berkuasa Negeri Sabah v. Sugumar Balakrishnan [2002] 1 MLRA 511, FC; Sugumar Balakrishnan v. Pengarah Imigresen Negeri Sabah & Anor & Another Appeal [1998] 1 MLRA 509 CA, Leong Pui Kun v. Lembaga Jurutera Malaysia [2001] 8 MLRH 494.

Other cases which discussed Art 5(1) against the validity of various legislations include the FCt decision of Che Ani Bin Itam v. Public Prosecutor [1983] 1 MLRA 351, Public Prosecutor v. Yee Kim Seng [1982] 1 MLRH 418, Rasid Bin Kulop Mohamad v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri & Ors [2004] 1 MLRH 455, Harmenderpall Singh A/L Jagara Singh v. Public Prosecutor [2004] 3 MLRH 70, Pihak Berkuasa Negeri Sabah v. Sugumar Balakrishnan [2002] 1 MLRA 511, Noor Ashid Bin Sakib v. Ketua Polis Negara [2001] 2 MLRH 317. In Md Aris Zainal Abidin v. Suruhanjaya Pasukan Polis & Anor [2002] 1 MLRA 506, CA, Tan Sri Dato' Tajuddin Ramli v. Pengurusan Danaharta Nasional Bhd & Ors [2002] 1 MLRH 281, Juraimi Bin Husin v. Lembaga Pengampunan, Negeri Pahang & Ors [2001] 2 MLRH 727, CA in Mohd Noor Bin Abdullah v. Nordin Bin Haji Zakaria & Anor [2001] 1 MLRA 181, per Gopal Sri Ram JCA, Krishnan Kutty A/L Sanguni Nair v. Telekom Malaysia Kawasan Utara & Anor [1999] 2 MLRH 163, Mohd Azmi FCJ in Ang Hiok Seng v. Yim Yut Kiu [1996] 2 MLRA 127, FC, Lord Diplock in Council Of Civil Service Unions v. Minister For Civil Service [1985] AC 374, [1984] 3 All ER 935, HL, Federal Court in Bato Bagi & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Sarawak & Another Appeal [2012] 1 MLRA 1, Suzana Md Aris v. DSP Ishak Hussain & Ors [2010] 1 MLRH 936, and Arbain Basri v. Ketua Polis Negara & Anor [2007] 4 MLRH 458

On the definition of the word 'Person' please refer to Repco Holdings Sdn Bhd & Ors v. Pengurusan Danaharta Nasional Bhd & Ors (No 2) [1999] 5 MLRH 226. See and Kesultanan Pahang v. Sathask Realty Sdn Bhd [1998] 1 MLRA 119, FC.

On the definition of the word 'life' please see the decision of Lembaga Tatatertib Perkhidmatan Awam, Hospital Besar Pulau Pinang v. Utra Badi A/L K Perumal [2000] 1 MLRA 278 CA, Kanawagi S/O Seperumaniam v. Penang Port Commission [2001] 5 MLRH 542, Tan Tek Seng @ Tan Chee Meng v. Suruhanjaya Perkhidmatan Pendidikan & Anor [1996] 1 MLRA 186, CA, and Ketua Pengarah Jabatan Alam Sekitar & Anor v. Kajing Tubek & Ors And Other Appeals [1997] 1 MLRA 474, CA and per Ian Chin J in Nor Anak Nyawai & Ors v. Borneo Pulp Plantation Sdn Bhd & Ors [2001] 1 MLRH 304.

Other cases which discussed 'life' and 'personal liberty' includes Kanawagi A/L Seperumaniam v. Dato' Abdul Hamid Bin Mohamad [2003] 7 MLRH 450, Public Prosecutor v. Ottavio Quattrocchi [2003] 1 MLRA 166, Ultra Dimension Sdn Bhd v. Kook Wei Kuan [2001] 5 MLRH 701, Krishnan A/L Sinniah lwn. Ketua Pegarah Imigresen Malaysia Dan Satu Lagi [2004] 5 MLRH 396 and also Peter James Tennet v. Kaka Singh Dhaliwal (Secretary of the Malayan Racing Association) [2009] 2 MLRA 437. See also FCt in Sivarasa Rasiah v. Badan Peguam Malaysia & Anor [2012] 6 MLRA 375. Affirming Lembaga Tatatertib Perkhidmatan Awam, Hospital Besar Pulau Pinang v. Utra Badi A/L K Perumal [2000] 1 MLRA 278, Tan Tek Seng @ Tan Chee Meng v. Suruhanjaya Perkhidmatan Pendidikan & Anor [1996] 1 MLRA 186 and Lee Kwan Woh v. PP [2009] 2 MLRA 286, CA in Muhamad Juzaili Mohd Khamis & Ors v. State Government Of Negeri Sembilan & Ors [2015] 1 MLRA 570, Zaki Tun Azmi CJ in the FC case of Bato Bagi & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Sarawak & Another Appeal [2012] 1 MLRA 1, CA in Yebet Saman & Ors v. Foong Kwai Long & Ors [2014] MLRAU 494. See also R Rama Chandran v. The Industrial Court Of Malaysia & Anor [1996] 1 MLRA 725; [1996] 1 MELR 71; Tan Tek Seng @ Tan Chee Meng v. Suruhanjaya Perkhidmatan Pendidikan & Anor [1996] 1 MLRA 186; Hong Leong Equipment Sdn Bhd v. Liew Fook Chuan And Another Appeal [1996] 2 MLRA 212; [1996] 1 MELR 142, HCt in Anas Abdul Kodir lwn. Jawatankuasa Tatatertib Kumpulan Sokongan Lembaga Pemasaran Pertanian Persekutuan (FAMA) Dan Yang Lain [2014] MLRHU 202, Dato' Dr Henry Ooi Kwee Lim v. Majlis Perubatan Malaysia [2011] 2 MLRH 901, HCt in Victoria Jayaseele Martin v. Majlis Agama Islam Wilayah Persekutuan & Anor [2011] 1 MLRH 344.

On "native customary rights' and the 'right to life' under Art 5 of the Federal Constitution, please see the HCt in Andawan Ansapi & Ors v. PP [2011] 4 MLRH 102. See also Pendor Banger & Ors v. Ketua Pengarah Jabatan Alam Sekitar & Ors [2011] 7 MLRH 877. Zaki Tun Azmi CJ in the FC case of Bato Bagi & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Sarawak & Another Appeal [2012] 1 MLRA 1, Nor Anak Nyawai & Ors v. Borneo Pulp Plantation Sdn Bhd & Ors [2001] 1 MLRH 304 and the HCt in Datuk Harris Mohd Salleh v. Datuk Yong Teck Lee & Anor [2012] 3 MLRH 226.

On the application of 'life' and/or 'personal liberty' see Government Of Malaysia v. Loh Wai Kong [1979] 1 MLRA 160, FC See also Kwan Hung Cheong v. Inspektor Yusof Hj Othman & Ors [2008] 3 MLRH 650, Law Pang Ching & Ors v. Tawau Municipal Council [2002] 4 MLRH 456, Public Prosecutor v. Ottavio Quattrocchi [2004] 1 MLRA 575, Ultra Dimension Sdn Bhd v. Kook Wei Kuan [2001] 5 MLRH 701, Subramaniam A/L Vythilingam v. Human Rights Commission Of Malaysia (SUHAKAM) & Ors [2003] 2 MLRH 170, Ooi Kean Thong & Anor v. PP [2006] 1 MLRA 565, Sivarasa Rasiah v. Badan Peguam Malaysia & Anor [2005] 2 MLRA 439, FC in Inspector Yusof Haji Othman & Ors v. Kwan Hung Cheong [2012] 1 MLRA 492, CA in PP v. Bird Dominic Jude [2014] 1 MLRA 317, FCt in Sivarasa Rasiah v. Badan Peguam Malaysia & Anor [2012] 6 MLRA 375 and the HCt in Lew Cher Phow & Ors v. Pua Yong Yong & Anor [2012] 1 MLRH 793.

The words 'law' and 'in accordance to law' was discussed in Che Ani Bin Itam v. Public Prosecutor [1983] 1 MLRA 351, FC; following Ong Ah Chuan v. Public Prosecutor [1980] 1 MLRA 283, [1981] AC 648, PC, Comptroller General Of Inland Revenue v. NP [1972] 1 MLRH 18 and Nallakaruppan A/L Solaimalai v. Ketua Pengarah Penjara, Malaysia & Ors [1998] 3 MLRH 467. The expression 'law' was also discussed and applied in Ng Kim Moi (P) & Ors v. Pentadbir Tanah Daerah, Seremban, Negeri Sembilan Darul Khusus (Negeri Sembilan Township Sdn Bhd & Anor, Proposed Intervenors) [2004] 1 MLRA 467, CA, Natarajan A/L K Maniam v. Dato' Chor Chee Heung & Anor [2002] 5 MLRH 333, Repco Holdings Sdn Bhd & Ors v. Pengurusan Danaharta Nasional Bhd & Ors (No 2) [1999] 5 MLRH 226, Public Prosecutor v. Ottavio Quattrocchi [2002] 3 MLRH 527, Rajeshkanna A/L Marimuthu v. Tn Hj Abd Wahab Bin Hj Kassim (Pengarah Penjara, Johor Bahru, Johor) [2003] 4 MLRH 117, PP v. Peter Kong [2007] 5 MLRH 391 (CT-45-11-2005-II g) (Kuching High Court)] and Public Prosecutor v. Chung Tshun Tin & Ors [2007] 1 MLRH 337. Other cases includes the CA decisions in Fam Meng Siong & Anor v. PP [2012] 3 MLRA 685, PP v. Bird Dominic Jude [2014] 1 MLRA 317, Zulkiflee SM Anwar Ulhaque & Anor v. Arikrishna Apparau & Ors [2013] MLRAU 398 referring to FC in Minister Of Home Affairs v. Chu Choon Yong & Anor [1977] 1 MLRA 425 and the FCt in Sivarasa Rasiah v. Badan Peguam Malaysia & Anor [2012] 6 MLRA 375.

On the application of Art 5(1), please refer to the following cases: Ahmad Mukamal Abdul Wahab & Ors v. PP [2013] MLRAU 84, Rozmi Yusof v. PP [2014] 4 MLRA 571, FC in Andrew S/O Thamboosamy v. Superintendent Of Pudu Prisons, Kuala Lumpur [1976] 1 MLRA 497 which was followed in CA in Zulkiflee SM Anwar Ulhaque & Anor v. Arikrishna Apparau & Ors [2013] MLRAU 398, CA in Ong Keng Tat v. PP [2015] 2 MLRA 323, and the HCt in Liaw Chee Huey v. Wong Chin Heon [2016] 1 MLRH 694.

ss. 5(3) and (4) of the Sarawak Land Code conforms with Art. 5(1) of the Federal Constitution as it expressly provide for the power of the Minister to extinguish native customary rights over land in the manner set out therein in clear and unambiguous terms. See CA in Bato Bagi & Ors v. Government Of The State Of Sarawak [2011] 1 MLRA 389 and FC in Bato Bagi & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Sarawak & Another Appeal [2012] 1 MLRA 1.

On the conduct of criminal procedure and Art 5 please see FC in Magendran Mohan v. PP [2012] 5 MLRA 333, quoted in PP v. Yap Chai Yee & Anor Appeal [2015] MLRAU 366. See also PP v. Ismail Abd Wahab [2014] 5 MLRA 527. Take note of opposing decision in the CA decision of PP v. Gan Boon Aun & Anor [2014] 3 MLRA 319 on Art 5(1) and what amounts to a delay in filing the appeal. See also HCt in Sundarajan Sokalingam v. Fredrick Indranxa Nicholas; Malaysian Bar Council (Intervener) [2014] MLRHU 416. Khairuddin Bin Mohd Yusuf v. Public Prosecutor [2005] 2 MLRA 799 followed by CA in Aung Thun & Anor v. PP [2013] MLRAU 270.
For a discussion on the burden of proof on Art 5(1) refer to the CA in Phrueksa Taemchim (Thailand) v. PP [2013] 6 MLRA 484.
On the relationship of Art 5(1) and Art 8(1) please see CA in PP v. Bird Dominic Jude [2014] 1 MLRA 317.

How does bankruptcy proceedings affect Art 5(1) of the FC? See CA in Ropli Ishak v. Hong Leong Leasing Sdn Bhd [2014] 2 MLRA 580, CA in Dato' Ramesh Rajaratnam v. Datin Zaleha Abd Rahman & Ors [2015] 1 MLRA 41, Sobri Arshad v. Associated Tractors Sdn Bhd [1991] 2 MLRH 349.
What is the effect of s 27 Evidence Act 1950 on Art 5(1) of the Federal Constitution? Please see the CA in Liang Weng Heng v. PP [2014] 3 MLRA 295
On a breach of Art 5(1) of the FC due to an unfocused judgment of the trial court please refer to the CA decision in Tong Kam Yew & anor v. PP [2014] 3 MLRA 490.
For the protection in Art 5(1) on civil cases, see the CA in Chin Kek Shen v. PP [2014] 3 MLRA 81 and the discussion therein.
On the relationship of s56A of the Courts of Judicature Act 1964 (CJA) and Art 5, see FCt in Bird Dominic Jude v. PP [2014] 4 MLRA 1.
On Winding-up proceedings and the effect on Art 5, please refer to HCt decision in Infovalley Life Sciences Sdn Bhd v. Srimelan Sdn Bhd [2015] 3 MLRH 34.

On the constitutional right of access to justice under Art 5(1) of the Federal Constitution, please refer to the HCt case of Lam Chee Keong & Ors v. Malaysian Airline System Berhad [2014] 5 MLRH 640 affirming FCt in Sivarasa Rasiah v. Badan Peguam Malaysia & Anor [2012] 6 MLRA 375. See also HCt in Universal Trustee (Malaysia) Berhad v. Lambang Pertama Sdn Bhd & Anor [2014] MLRHU 457 and Walvin Soudara Nathan v. PP [2014] MLRHU 1397.
Can s 114(g) of EA 1950 whittled away Art 5(1)? Please refer to CA in Chin Kek Shen v. PP [2014] 3 MLRA 81 and the discussion therein.

On Art 5(1) and right to a fair trial, please see the decision of the CA in Mohd Asmawi Mohd Ali lwn. Pendakwa Raya [2014] MLRAU 295, Mohd Hanafi Safii v. PP [2013] 5 MLRA 559, following the FCt in Lee Kwan Woh v. PP [2009] 2 MLRA 286; See also Nadzri Nordin lwn. Pendakwa Raya [2012] 3 MLRA 48

Other cases which applies Art 5 on the various law and legislations includes the CA in Penguasa Tempat Tahanan Perlindungan Kamunting, Taiping & Anor v. Badrul Zaman PS Md Zakariah [2016] 1 MLRA 267, CA in Nurasmira Maulat Abd Jaffar & Ors v. Ketua Polis Negara & Ors [2014] 6 MLRA 531, the HCt of Kamalan Shaik Mohd v. PP [2014] 2 MLRH 110 and PP v. Elancoven Singaram [2013] MLRHU 1078 and Kamalan Shaik Mohd v. PP [2014] 2 MLRH 110. See also Sepakat Efektif Sdn Bhd v. Menteri Dalam Negeri & Anor And Another Appeal [2014] 6 MLRA 412 and Mkini Dotcom Sdn Bhd v. Menteri Dalam Negeri & Anor [2014] MLRAU 351, CA in Othman A Aziz v. PP [2014] 6 MLRA 54 following FC in Shamim Reza Abdul Samad v. Public Prosecutor [2009] 2 MLRA 677, CA in Teoh Meng Kee v. PP [2014] 5 MLRA 404, KTL Sdn Bhd & Anor v. Leong Oow Lai [2014] MLRHU 1014, Re: Jagvinder Singh Maghar Singh; Ex-Parte: Mohd Radzi Ismail & Ors [2014] MLRHU 502 and the CA in Koperasi Keretapi Berhad v. Menteri Kewangan Malaysia & Ors [2013] 4 MLRA 143
On Art 5(1) and the assessment of damages for unlawful detention please see the HCt case of Mahfuz Omar v. Inspektor Mohd Zaid Madzizat & Ors And Another Appeal [2013] 1 MLRH 189.

On the failure of the police to act within section 23(1) CPC or with respect to the rights of arrested persons, please see the discussion in the HCt in Sivarasa Rasiah & Ors v. Che Hamzah Che Ismail & Ors [2011] 5 MLRH 740

On the general application of Art 5 please refer to the HCt in Vasanthi Maruthamuthu & Ors v. Superintendant Azman Salim Ketua Polis Daerah Sunga Siput & Ors [2014] MLRHU 545, HCt in N Indra Nallathamby v. Datuk Seri Khalid Abu Bakar & Ors [2013] 4 MLRH 441, Kamalan Shaik Mohd v. PP [2014] 2 MLRH 110, HCt in Dr Muhamad Fadly Ramly @ Hashim v. Brig Jen (Dr) Dato' Hj Samiran & Ors [2013] MLRHU 193, Mohamad Sabu lwn. Pendakwa Raya [2013] 6 MLRH 613, Dato Sreesanthan Eliathamby lwn. Pendakwa Raya Dan Kes Yang Lain [2013] MLRHU 1310, Jeno Jo & Anor v. The State Government Of Sarawak [2012] MLRHU 1816, Sakri Yadam & Satu Lagi lwn. Pendakwa Raya [2012] 4 MLRH 523, Luking Uding & Ors v. Superintendent Of Lands And Surveys Kota Samarahan Division & Ors [2011] 1 MLRH 376, CA in Borhan Hj Daud & Ors v. Abd Malek Hussin [2010] 2 MLRA 377

p.i: The words "a High Court" which appear in line one were substituted for the words "the Supreme Court" by Act 26/1963, section 70, in force from 16-09-1963.

NOTE.p: The words 'Unlawfully detained' was discussed and applied in the following cases: see Re Onkar Shrian [1969] 1 MLRH 160. Referred to by the Federal Court in Sejahratul Dursina @ Chomel Bte Abdullah v. Kerajaan Malaysia & Ors [2005] 2 MLRA 671, FCt in Sejahratul Dursina @ Chomel Bte Abdullah v. Kerajaan Malaysia & Ors [2005] 2 MLRA 671, Kiong Ping Moon @ Kong Ping Sen lwn. Timbalan Menteri Keselamatan Dalam Negeri Dan Lain-Lain [2005] 5 MLRH 252, Sukma Darmawan Sasmitaat Madja v. Ketua Pengarah Penjara Malaysia & Anor [1998] 2 MLRA 301, CA. See also Madjai Bin Sanusi v. Pengarah Imigresen, Johor & Ors [1999] 3 MLRH 285, Hii Hieng Lee v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri Malaysia & Ors [2004] 1 MLRH 426 and Rajeshkanna A/L Marimuthu v. Tn Hj Abd Wahab Bin Hj Kassim (Pengarah Penjara, Johor Bahru, Johor) [2003] 4 MLRH 117.

The words 'The court shall inquire' was considered in the cases of Noor Ashid Bin Sakib v. Ketua Polis Negara [2001] 2 MLRH 317 and per Abu Mansor JCA in Ahmad Bashid Bin Abdul Malek & Ors v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri & Ors And Other Appeals [1999] 1 MLRA 409, CA.

The words 'Shall order him to be produced before the court' was discussed in Abdul Ghani Haroon v. Ketua Polis Negara And Another Application (No 4) [2001] 1 MLRH 679, Ketua Polis Negara v. Abdul Ghani Haroon [2001] 1 MLRA 436, FC, per Haidar JCA, Azizah Bte Shaik Ismail & Anor v. Fatimah Bte Shaik Ismail & Anor [2002] 3 MLRH 25.

On the application of Art 5(2) and the Writ of Habeas Corpus see HCt decisions of Choo Soon An v. The Deputy Minister Of Home Affairs, Malaysia & Ors [2012] 3 MLRH 11; Suthagar Rajamoney v. The Deputy Minister Of Home Affairs, Malaysia & Ors [2011] 9 MLRH 301, Tey Ai Lee v. The Deputy Minister Of Home Affairs, Malaysia & Ors [2012] 4 MLRH 77, FCt in Darma Suria Risman Saleh v. Meneri Dalam Negeri, Malaysia & Ors [2012] 6 MLRA 607, HCt case of Ang Kok Wee v. The Deputy Minister Of Home Affairs, Malaysia & Ors [2011] 10 MLRH 650 and the Federal Court in Sejahratul Dursina @ Chomel Bte Abdullah v. Kerajaan Malaysia & Ors [2005] 2 MLRA 671.

Other cases on Habeas Corpus includes Re Meenal W/O Muniyandi [1979] 1 MLRH 369, Yeap Hock Seng @ Ah Seng v. Minister For Home Affairs, Malaysia & Ors [1975] 1 MLRH 378; Sazali Bin Mat Noh v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri & Ors [1998] 2 MLRH 426, Karam Singh v. Menteri Hal Ehwal Dalam Negeri, Malaysia [1969] 1 MLRA 412 FC, Ahmad Bashid Bin Abdul Malek & Ors v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri & Ors And Other Appeals [1999] 1 MLRA 409, CA. See also Mohamad Isa Bin Zakaria v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri Malaysia & Ors [2000] 5 MLRH 360; Azizah Bte Shaik Ismail & Anor v. Fatimah Bte Shaik Ismail & Anor [2002] 3 MLRH 25, where the court dealt with the relevant law concerning habeas corpus and custody of Muslim children; Noor Ashid Bin Sakib v. Ketua Polis Negara [2001] 2 MLRH 317; Hairul Hisham Salim v. Dato' Zainal Abidin Zin & Anor [2002] 3 MLRH 631; Kandupillai Krishnan v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri, Malaysia & Ors [2003] 2 MLRH 875; Tee Yam @ Koo Tee Yam v. Timbalan Menteri, Menteri Keselamatan Dalam Negeri, Malaysia & Ors [2005] 2 MLRH 369; Krishnamorrthi A/L Kathurayan v. Timbalan Menteri Keselamatan Dalam Negeri, Malaysia & Ors [2005] 4 MLRH 764; Federal Court decision in Abdul Razak Bin Baharudin & Ors v. Ketua Polis Negara & Ors And Another Appeal [2005] 2 MLRA 109; Arasa Kumaran A/L Tulasi & Ors v. Timbalan Menteri Keselamatan Dalam Negeri & Ors [2006] 1 MLRH 137

On the objective and effect of habeas corpus please see the following cases: Re Datuk James Wong Kim Min [1976] 1 MLRA 132, Ex Parte Johannes Choeldi & Ors [1960] 1 MLRH 181, referred by the Federal Court in Muhammad Jailani Bin Kasim v. Timbalan Menteri Keselamatan Dalam Negeri, Malaysia & Ors [2006] 2 MLRA 230, Mohd Raymee Bin Ismail v. Ketua Komandan, Pusat Serenti Tiang Dua & Anor [1998] 3 MLRH 493. Cf Wong Kon That & Ors v. Ketua Komandan Pusat Serenti Karangan, Kulim & Anor [1998] 3 MLRH 520. See also Sejahratul Dursina @ Chomel Bte Abdullah v. Kerajaan Malaysia & Ors [2005] 2 MLRA 671, FC; Muhammad Jailani Bin Kasim v. Timbalan Menteri Keselamatan Dalam Negeri, Malaysia & Ors [2006] 2 MLRA 230, Abdul Ghani Haroon v. Ketua Polis Negara And Another Application [2001] 1 MLRH 189, Nik Adli Bin Nik Abdul Aziz v. Ketua Polis Negara [2001] 4 MLRH 134, Nasharuddin Bin Nasir v. Kerajaan Malaysia & Ors (No 2) [2002] 3 MLRH 398 which summarized the relevant changes in the law of habeas corpus brought about by Mohamad Ezam Bin Mohd Noor v. Ketua Polis Negara & Other Appeals [2002] 2 MLRA 46, FC.

Other cases includes Mahkamah Majistret Rawang & Anor v. Gurdeep Singh A/L Atma Singa [2000] 1 MLRH 120, Lee Kew Sang v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri Malaysia & Ors [2005] 1 MLRA 692 the court in Tee Yam @ Koo Tee Yam v. Timbalan Menteri, Menteri Keselamatan Dalam Negeri, Malaysia & Ors [2005] 2 MLRH 369, Noor Ashid Bin Sakib v. Ketua Polis Negara [2001] 2 MLRH 317, Muhammad Atam Bin Abdul Wahab v. Minister Of Home Affairs [2000] 3 MLRH 289, Ketua Polis Negara v. Abdul Ghani Haroon [2001] 1 MLRA 436 , FC, Is the principle of res judicata applicable to criminal matters and habeas corpus applications? See the High Court in Rakesh A/L Ram Tawar v. Timbalan Menteri Keselamatan Dalam Negeri, Malaysia And Others [2008] 1 MLRH 591.

Further discussion on the writ of Habeas Corpus can be found in the following cases: Re Gurbachan Singh's Application [1966] 1 MLRH 192, Re Gurdit Singh [1930] 1 MLRH 445; Datuk Harun Bin Haji Idris v. Officer-In-Charge, Pudu Prison [1981] 1 MLRA 590, FC, Madjai Bin Sanusi v. Pengarah Imigresen, Johor & Ors [1999] 3 MLRH 285, Mad Yaacob Bin Ismail & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Kelantan & Anor [2001] 1 MLRH 234, Ahmad Bashid Bin Abdul Malek & Ors v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri & Ors And Other Appeals [1999] 1 MLRA 409, CA, Abdul Ghani Haroon v. Ketua Polis Negara And Another Application [2001] 1 MLRH 189. See also Abdul Ghani Haroon v. Ketua Polis Negara and Another Application (No 2) [2001] 1 MLRH 264; Abdul Ghani Haroon v. Ketua Polis Negara And Another Application (No 3) [2001] 1 MLRH 268; and Abdul Ghani Haroon v. Ketua Polis Negara And Another Application (No 4) [2001] 1 MLRH 679, Re Mohamad Ezam Bin Mohd Nor [2001] 4 MLRH 744, SK Tangakaliswaran Krishnan v. Menteri Dalam Negeri, Malaysia & Ors [2009] 2 MLRA 631, Murally Krishnan v. The Deputy Minister Of Home Affairs, Malaysia & Ors [2012] 4 MLRH 160, HCt in Sivarasa Rasiah & Ors v. Che Hamzah Che Ismail & Ors [2011] 5 MLRH 740.
Definition

For a discussion on the word 'Informed ... of the grounds of his arrest' please see Re PE Long @ Jimmy & Ors; PE Long & Ors v. Menteri Hal Ehwal Dalam Negeri Malaysia & Ors [1977] 1 MLRH 519, Chong Kim Loy v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri Malaysia & Anor [1989] 2 MLRH 378. See also Chuah Say Phang lwn. Tuan Majistret Mahkamah Majistret Gerik, Perak Darul Ridzuan Dan Satu Lagi [2000] 2 MLRH 194. In Kam Teck Soon v. Timbalan Menteri Dalam Negeri Malaysia & Ors And Other Appeals [2002] 2 MLRA 268, the judgment of Suriyadi Halim Omar J in the case of Nasharuddin Nasir v. Kerajaan Malaysia & Ors [2002] 3 MLRH 392 and the Federal Court in Kerajaan Malaysia & Ors v. Nasharuddin Nasir [2003] 2 MLRA 399, FC. See further, Munisvaran Kannan v. Menteri Hal Ehwal Dalam Negeri Malaysia & Anor [2004] 1 MLRH 254; and Chuah Say Phang lwn. Tuan Majistret Mahkamah Majistret Gerik, Perak Darul Ridzuan Dan Satu Lagi [2000] 2 MLRH 194, Abdul Ghani Haroon v. Ketua Polis Negara And Another Application [2001] 1 MLRH 189, Nik Adli Bin Nik Abdul Aziz v. Ketua Polis Negara [2001] 4 MLRH 134. See Abdul Ghani Haroon v. Ketua Polis Negara And Another Application (No 3) [2001] 1 MLRH 268, Lee Chan Leong v. Jurutera Konsultant (SEA) Sdn Bhd & Ors [2002] 1 MLRA 500, Ex Parte Johannes Choeldi & Ors [1960] 1 MLRH 181 followed in Ng Hong Choon v. Timbalan Menteri Hal Ehwal Dalam Negeri [1994] 4 MLRH 713. Other cases include Cooper v. Wandsworth Board of Works [1863] 14 CB(NS) 180, Goldsberg v. Kelly [1970] 397 US 254 pp 268-269; Richard v. Wright [1972] 405 US 208 pp 215-216 per Brennan J) Abbott v. Sullivan [1952] 1 KB 189 at p 198, AR Antulay v. RS Nayak 1988 2 SCC 602, Ravi S Naik v. Union of India 1994 supp(2) SCC 641), Ng Hong Choon v. Timbalan Menteri Hal Ehwal Dalam Negeri [1994] 4 MLRH 713, Tan Yap Seng v. Ketua Polis Negara & Ors [1991] 2 MLRH 570, Che Hong Yee v. Timbalan Menteri Keselamatan Dalam Negeri, Malaysia & Ors [2007] 5 MLRH 856.

On the words 'As soon as may be' please refer to these cases for an in depth discussion. See Aminah v. Art 5(5)

SECTION.p: (1) No person shall be held in slavery.
(2) All forms of forced labour are prohibited, but Parliament may by law provide for compulsory service for national purposes.

(3) Work or service required from any person as a consequence of a conviction or a finding of guilt in a court of law shall not be taken to be forced labour within the meaning of this Article, provided that such work or service is carried out under the supervision and control of a public authority.

(4) Where by any written law the whole or any part of the functions of any public authority is to be carried on by another public authority, for the purpose of enabling those functions to be performed the employees of the first-mentioned public authority shall be bound to serve the second-mentioned public authority, and their service with the second-mentioned public authority shall not be taken to be forced labour within the meaning of this Article, and no such employee shall be entitled to demand any right from either the first-mentioned or the second-mentioned public authority by reason of the transfer of his employment.

NOTE.p: See Barat Estates Sdn Bhd & Anor v. Parawakan A/L Subramaniam & Ors [2000] 1 MLRA 404, CA, per Gopal Sri Ram JCA's decision on the application of Art 6(1).
Per Gopal Sri Ram JCA in Barat Estates Sdn Bhd & Anor v. Parawakan A/L Subramaniam & Ors [2000] 1 MLRA 404, CA also referred to and discussed Art 6(2).

p.i: The present Clause was inserted by Act A1130, section 2, in force from 28-09-2001, and replaced the earlier Clause which read as follows:
"(3) Work incidental to the serving of a sentence of imprisonment imposed by a court of law shall not be taken to be forced labour within the meaning of this Article.".
Added by Act A354, section 5, in force from 27-08-1976.

b.ST: Protection against retrospective criminal laws and repeated trials.

SECTION.p: (1) No person shall be punished for an act or omission which was not punishable by law when it was done or made, and no person shall suffer greater punishment for an offence than was prescribed by law at the time it was committed.

(2) A person who has been acquitted or convicted of an offence shall not be tried again for the same offence except where the conviction or acquittal has been quashed and a retrial ordered by a court superior to that by which he was acquitted or convicted.

NOTE.p: Art 7(1)

In Zakaria Abdul Rahman v. See also the Privy Council's decision in Harry Lee Wee v. Law Society Of Singapore [1984] 1 MLRA 858, PC, there should have been only one charge and the first charge in the second proceedings should be set aside.

Art 7(2)

SECTION.p: (1) All persons are equal before the law and entitled to the equal protection of the law.

(2) Except as expressly authorized by this Constitution, there shall be no discrimination against citizens on the ground only of religion, race, descent, place of birth or gender in any law or in the appointment to any office or employment under a public authority or in the administration of any law relating to the acquisition, holding or disposition of property or the establishing or carrying on of any trade, business, profession, vocation or employment.
(3) There shall be no discrimination in favour of any person on the ground that he is a subject of the Ruler of any State.
(4) No public authority shall discriminate against any person on the ground that he is resident or carrying on business in any part of the Federation outside the jurisdiction of the authority.
(5) This Article does not invalidate or prohibit-

blockquote.p: (a) any provision regulating personal law;

(b) any provisions or practice restricting office or employment connected with the affairs of any religion or of an institution managed by a group professing any religion, to persons professing that religion;

(c) any provision for the protection, well-being or advancement of the aboriginal peoples of the Malay Peninsula (including the reservation of land) or the reservation to aborigines of a reasonable proportion of suitable positions in the public service;

(d) any provision prescribing residence in a State or part of a State as a qualification for election or appointment to any authority having jurisdiction only in that State or part, or for voting in such an election;
(e) any provision of a Constitution of a State, being or corresponding to a provision in force immediately before Merdeka Day;
(f) any provision restricting enlistment in the Malay Regiment to Malays.

p.i: Clause (2): The words "descent, place of birth or gender" were substituted for "descent or place of birth" by Act A1130, section 3, in force from 28-09-2001.
Clause (5)(c): The words "Malay Peninsula" were substituted for "Federation" by Act 26/1963, section 70, in force from 16-09-1963.
Clause (5)(f): See section 6, Armed Forces Act 1972 [Act 77].

b.ST: Prohibition of banishment and freedom of movement.

SECTION.p: (1) No citizen shall be banished or excluded from the Federation.

(2) Subject to Clause (3) and to any law relating to the security of the Federation or any part thereof, public order, public health, or the punishment of offenders, every citizen has the right to move freely throughout the Federation and to reside in any part thereof.

(3) So long as under this Constitution any other State is in a special position as compared with the States of Malaya, Parliament may by law impose restrictions, as between that State and other States, on the rights conferred by Clause (2) in respect of movement and residence.

p.i: See Art. 149 (1).

NOTE.p: Art 9(1)
This was applied in Ex P Tan Kheng Long (1958) 3 MC 205 and Kung Aik v. Public Prosecutor [1970] 1 MLRH 510.

p.i: Clause (2):

1. The words "Subject to Clause (3) and to any law relating to the security of the Federation or any part thereof" which appear at the commencement were substituted for the words "Subject to any restriction imposed by any law relating to the security of the Federation" by Act 26/1963, subsection 60 (1), in force from 16-09-1963.

NOTE.p: Art 9(2)

Please refer to the following cases which discussed and applied this Article: Federal Court in Assa Singh v. Mentri Besar Johor [1968] 1 MLRA 886, Government Of Malaysia v. Loh Wai Kong [1979] 1 MLRA 160, FC (on the right to leave the country). See also Adong Bin Kuwau & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Johor & Anor [1997] 3 MLRH 95 which was approved by the Court of Appeal in Kerajaan Negeri Johor & Anor v. Adong Bin Kuwau & Ors [1998] 1 MLRA 170, CA, per Gopal Sri Ram JCA. See also CA in Muhamad Juzaili Mohd Khamis & Ors v. State Government Of Negeri Sembilan & Ors [2015] 1 MLRA 570 on Art 9(2) and its effect onSection 66 of the Syariah Criminal Enactment 1992 (Negeri Sembilan).

p.i: 2. See Art. 4 (2)(a).
Clause (3):

1. This Clause was added by Act 26/1963, subsection 60(1), in force from 16-09-1963. A proviso which was added at the same time was repealed by Act 59/1966, section 2, in force from 19-09-1966. As it stood on the date of repeal, the proviso read as follows:

"Provided that no restriction on the right of movement between the State of Singapore and the States of Malaya shall be imposed by virtue of this Clause except by a law relating to labour or education or to any matter in respect of which, because of the special position of the State of Singapore, it appears to Parliment to be desirable to prevent the enjoyment of rights both in the State of Singapore and in the States of Malaya.".
2. This Clause (3) applies to laws passed before Malaysia Day so as to impose restrictions with effect from Malaysia Day-Act 26/1963, subsection 60(2).

3. The proviso of Clause (3) was amended by the addition of "and any such restriction shall apply reciprocally to the State of Malaya and the State of Singapore" at the end of the proviso by Act 19/ 1964, section 2, in force from 30-07-1964.

NOTE.p: Art 9(3)

This article was discussed and applied in Datuk Syed Kechik Bin Syed Mohamed v. Government Of Malaysia [1978] 1 MLRA 504, FC (on immigration and the States of Sabah and Sarawak) and the FCt in Pihak Berkuasa Negeri Sabah v. Sugumar Balakrishnan [2002] 1 MLRA 511 (per Mohamed Dzaiddin FCJ).

b.ST: Freedom of speech, assembly and association.

SECTION.p: (1) Subject to Clauses (2), (3) and (4)-

blockquote.p: (a) every citizen has the right to freedom of speech and expression;
(b) all citizens have the right to assemble peaceably and without arms;
(c) all citizens have the right to form associations.

SECTION.p: (2) Parliament may by law impose-

blockquote.p: (a) on the rights conferred by paragraph (a) of Clause (1), such restrictions as it deems necessary or expedient in the interest of the security of the Federation or any part thereof, friendly relations with other countries, public order or morality and restrictions designed to protect the privileges of Parliament or of any Legislative Assembly or to provide against contempt of court, defamation, or incitement to any offence;
(b) on the right conferred by paragraph (b) of Clause (1), such restrictions as it deems necessary or expedient in the interest of the security of the Federation or any part thereof or public order;

(c) on the right conferred by paragraph (c) of Clause (1), such restrictions as it deems necessary or expedient in the interest of the security of the Federation or any part thereof, public order or morality.

SECTION.p: (3) Restrictions on the right to form associations conferred by paragraph (c) of Clause (1) may also be imposed by any law relating to labour or education.

(4) In imposing restrictions in the interest of the security of the Federation or any part thereof or public order under Clause (2)(a), Parliament may pass law prohibiting the questioning of any matter, right, status, position, privilege, sovereignty or prerogative established or protected by the provisions of Part III, Article 152, 153 or 181 otherwise than in relation to the implementation thereof as may be specified in such law.

p.i: See Art. 149 (1).
Clause (1): The word "Subject to Clauses (2), (3) and (4)" substituted for "Subject to Clauses (2) and (3)" by Act A30, section 2, in force 10-03-1971.

p.i: Clause (3) was added by Act 26/1963, subsection 60 (4), in force from 16-09-1963, which also amended Clause (1) by substituting the words "Clauses (2) and (3)" for "Clause (2)" appearing at the commencement of the Clause.
Clause (4) added by Act A30, section 2, in force from 10-03-1971.

SECTION.p: (1) Every person has the right to profess and practise his religion and, subject to Clause (4), to propagate it.
(2) No person shall be compelled to pay any tax the proceeds of which are specially allocated in whole or in part for the purposes of a religion other than his own.
(3) Every religious group has the right-

blockquote.p: (a) to manage its own religious affairs;
(b) to establish and maintain institutions for religious or charitable purposes; and
(c) to acquire and own property and hold and administer it in accordance with law.

SECTION.p: (4) State law and in respect of the Federal Territories of Kuala Lumpur, Labuan and Putrajaya, federal law may control or restrict the propagation of any religious doctrine or belief among persons professing the religion of Islam.
(5) This Article does not authorize any act contrary to any general law relating to public order, public health or morality.

Public Services Commission, Malaysia & Anor [1994] 1 MLRA 252; Fatimah Bte Sihi & Ors v. Meor Atiqulrahman Bin Ishak & Ors [2004] 2 MLRA 597.

On the usage of the word "Allah" and Art 11(1), please see the CA in Menteri Dalam Negeri & Ors v. Titular Roman Catholic Archbishop Of Kuala Lumpur [2013] 6 MLRA 8.

Art 11 was applied in the these cases. They are Siti Hasnah Vangarama Abdullah v. Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad & Ors [2012] 6 MLRA 687. See also Jill Ireland Lawrence Bill v. Menteri Bagi Kementerian Dalam Negeri Malaysia & Anor [2014] MLRHU 886, Deepa Subramaniam v. Viran Nagapan (Encl 37) [2014] MLRHU 462, Lina Joy v. Majlis Agama Islam Wilayah Persekutuan & Anor [2001] 5 MLRH 718 followed in the HCt in Mohd Jefrey Mohd Baser v. Ketua Pengarah Jabatan Pendaftaran Negara & Anor And Other Cases [2015] 6 MLRH 194.

On the issue whether the removal of Christian celebration days as public holidays had violated the religious freedom under Art 11 of the Fed Consti, please see the HCt case of Marcel Jude Ms Joseph v. Sabah State Legislative Assembly [2014] 1 MLRH 673.

On how the construction of singular or plural words under Art 160(1) is applied to Art 11(1), please refer to the HCt case of Indira Gandhi Mutho v. Pengarah Jabatan Agama Islam Perak & Ors [2013] 5 MLRH 111.

On religious issues including the word "Allah" and Art 11 please see cases like Meor Atiqulrahman Bin Ishak & Ors v. Fatimah Bte Sihi & Ors [2006] 2 MLRA 33 and Subashini A/P Rajasingam v. Saravanan A/L Thangathoray And Other Appeals [2007] 3 MLRA 81 and the FCt case of Titular Roman Catholic Archbishop Of Kuala Lumpur v. Menteri Dalam Negeri & Ors [2014] 4 MLRA 205.
See Lina Joy v. Majlis Agama Islam Wilayah & Anor [2001] 5 MLRH 718 for the application of this Article.

p.i: 1. The words "and in respect of the Federal Territory, federal law" were inserted after "State law" in line one by Act A206, Schedule, in force from 01-02-1974. The words "religion of Islam" substituted for "Muslim religion" by Act A354, section 45, in force from 27-08-1976.
2. Subsequently the words "Territories of Kuala Lumpur and Labuan" were substituted for the word "Territory" by Act A585, Schedule, in force from 16-04-1984.
3. The words "Kuala Lumpur, Labuan and Putrajaya" were substituted for "Kuala Lumpur and Labuan" by Act A1095, section 13, in force from 01-02-2001.

NOTE.p: General Note

The principles of Art 11(4) are established in the cases of Mamat Bin Daud & Ors v. Government Of Malaysia [1987] 1 MLRA 292, SC, Lina Joy v. Majlis Agama Islam Wilayah & Anor [2001] 5 MLRH 718, Court of Appeal cases of Lina Joy v. Majlis Agama Islam Wilayah Persekutuan & Ors [2005] 2 MLRA 271, Menteri Dalam Negeri & Ors v. Titular Roman Catholic Archbishop Of Kuala Lumpur [2013] 6 MLRA 8 and Menteri Dalam Negeri & Ors v. Titular Roman Catholic Archbishop Of Kuala Lumpur [2013] 6 MLRA 8.

On the application of Art 11(4) on the word 'Allah' please refer to the CA in Jerry Wa Dusing & Anor v. Menteri Keselamatan Dalam Negeri Malaysia & Anor [2015] 2 MLRA 48 which distinguished the Federal Court in Titular Roman Catholic Archbishop Of Kuala Lumpur v. Menteri Dalam Negeri & Ors [2014] 4 MLRA 205.
Article 11(5)
This Article was applied in Halimatussaadiah v. Public Service Commission, Malaysia & Anor [1992] 1 MLRH 684, per Eusoff Chin J.

SECTION.p: (1) Without prejudice to the generality of Article 8, there shall be no discrimination against any citizen on the grounds only of religion, race, descent or place of birth-

blockquote.p: (a) in the administration of any educational institution maintained by a public authority, and, in particular, the admission of pupils or students or the payment of fees; or

(b) in providing out of the funds of a public authority financial aid for the maintenance or education of pupils or students in any educational institution (whether or not maintained by a public authority and whether within or outside the Federation).

SECTION.p: (2) Every religious group has the right to establish and maintain institutions for the education of children in its own religion, and there shall be no discrimination on the ground only of religion in any law relating to such institutions or in the administration of any such law; but it shall be lawful for the Federation or a State to establish or maintain or assist in establishing or maintaining Islamic institutions or provide or assist in providing instruction in the religion of Islam and incur such expenditure as may be necessary for the purpose.
(3) No person shall be required to receive instruction in or to take part in any ceremony or act of worship of a religion other than his own.
(4) For the purposes of Clause (3) the religion of a person under the age of eighteen years shall be decided by his parent or guardian.

p.i: 1. The present Clause (2) was inserted by Act A354, section 6, in force from 27-08-1976, and replaced the earlier Clause which read as follows:

"(2) Every religious group has the right to establish and maintain institutions for the education of children and provide therein instruction in its own religion, and there shall be no discrimination on the ground only of religion in any law relating to such institutions or in the administration of any such law, but federal law or State law may provide for special financial aid for the establishment or maintenance of Muslim institution or the instruction in the Muslim religion of persons professing that religion.".
2. The words "or State law" which appear in line four above after "federal law" were inserted by Act 25/1963, subsection 2(1), in force from 31-08-1957 vide subsection 3 (3).

NOTE.p: Please refer to the FCt in Haji Raimi Abdullah v. Siti Hasnah Vangarama Abdullah & Another Appeal [2014] 3 MLRA 173 on the application of this Article.

On the definition of the word 'Parent' please refer to the case of Chang Ah Mee v. Jabatan Hal Ehwal Agama Islam & Ors [2002] 3 MLRH 477 and the Federal Court in Subashini A/P Rajasingam v. Saravanan A/L Thangathoray And Other Appeals [2007] 3 MLRA 81.

On the application of this Article, please see Re Susie Teoh, Teoh Eng Huat v. Khadi Of Pasir Mas Kelantan And Majlis Ugama Islam Dan Adat Istiadat Melayu, Kelantan [1986] 2 MLRH 649, FCt in Haji Raimi Abdullah v. Siti Hasnah Vangarama Abdullah & Another Appeal [2014] 3 MLRA 173(supra), Siti Hasnah Vangarama Abdullah v. Tun Dr Mahathir Mohamad & Ors [2012] 6 MLRA 687 and Indira Gandhi Mutho v. Pengarah Jabatan Agama Islam Perak & Ors [2013] 5 MLRH 111

SECTION.p: (1) No person shall be deprived of property save in accordance with law.
(2) No law shall provide for the compulsory acquisition or use of property without adequate compensation.

NOTE.p: The word 'deprived of' was considered in the cases of Government Of Malaysia v. Selangor Pilot Association [1977] 1 MLRA 258 affirmed by Ong See Teong & Anor v. Tenaga Nasional Bhd [2009] 1 MLRA 453

The word 'Property' was discussed in the following cases; they include Government Of Malaysia v. Selangor Pilot Association [1977] 1 MLRA 258, PC, Station Hotels Bhd v. Malayan Railway Administration [1976] 1 MLRA 209, FC, where the Federal Court held that a contract for termination of a lease by a lessor was not property within Art 13, Manoharan A/L Dorasamy v. Ketua Polis Ibu Pejabat Kontinjen Polis Seremban, Negeri Sembilan & Anor [2001] 1 MLRA 679, CA, and Ketua Polis Ibu Pejabat Kontinjen Polis Seremban, Negeri Sembilan & Anor v. Manoharan A/L Dorasamy [2003] 2 MLRA 191, FC, where the courts held in both instances that the appellant had suffered damages owing to the unlawful detention of a vehicle. See also Janaveloo A/L Kuppusamy lwn. Ketua Polis Balai Polis Sentul Wilayah Persekutuan Dan Satu Lagi [2006] 1 MLRA 478, Federal Court in Minister Of Finance, Government Of Sabah v. Petrojasa Sdn Bhd [2008] 1 MLRA 705, the CA in Yayasan Bumiputera Sabah & anor v. Apoview Wood Products Sdn Bhd [2012] 5 MLRA 410, CA in Wong Sew Yun & Ors v. Chelingga Asuh [2012] 5 MLRA 153, CA Loh Fung Ting v. Sarawak Electricity Supply Corporatio (SESCO) [2014] MLRAU 323; See dissenting judgment of Abdul Wahab Patail JCA applying Art 13.

On whether a judgment can be considered as 'property' within Art 13, please see the CA in Koperasi Pegawai-Pegawai Kerajaan Negeri Perlis Berhad v. Wan Kia @ Wan Noriah Mahat [2013] MLRAU 354 and CA in Osaka Resources Sdn Bhd & ors v. Foo Holdings Sdn Bhd [2013] MLRAU 353. See also CA in Superintendent Of Lands And Surveys, Kuching Division & Ors v. Kuching Waterfront Development Sdn Bhd [2009] 2 MLRA 659

In the absence of reasonable cause required under the Customs Act, the seizure and detention of the plaintiff's motorcar is unlawful and contrary to Art 13(1). HCt in Chia Sia Chek v. Ketua Pengarah Kastam, Jabatan Kastam Diraja Malaysia & Ors [2008] 3 MLRH 424. See also Loh Kam Hon v. Ketua Pengarah Kastam Diraja Malaysia [2011] 13 MLRH 350

On 'Property' and the Orang Asli, please see the cases of Sagong Tasi & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Selangor & Ors [2002] 1 MLRH 161, Adong Bin Kuwau & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Johor & Anor [1997] 3 MLRH 95, Kerajaan Negeri Selangor & Ors v. Sagong Bin Tasi & Ors [2005] 1 MLRA 819, CA, in Kerajaan Negeri Johor & Anor v. Adong Bin Kuwau & Ors [1998] 1 MLRA 170, Nor Anak Nyawai & Ors v. Borneo Pulp Plantation Sdn Bhd & Ors [2001] 1 MLRH 304; Chong Chung Moi @ Christine Chong v. Government Of The State Of Sabah & Ors [2007] 6 MLRH 730 and Superintendent Of Lands & Surveys, Bintulu v. Nor Anak Nyawai & Ors And Another Appeal [2005] 1 MLRA 580. Further references can be made to the cases of Jalang Anak Paran & Anor v. Government Of The State Of Sarawak & Anor [2010] 3 MLRA 573 which was referred and applied by Bato Bagi and Others v. Government Of The State Of Sarawak [2008] 2 MLRH 160, FCt in Bato Bagi & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Sarawak & Another Appeal [2012] 1 MLRA 1, Tamit Anak Anjat & Ors v. Fung Tai Sdn Bhd & Ors [2015] 5 MLRA 54 CA, Malaysia Anak Bang & Ors v. Empresa (M) Sdn Bhd & Anor And Another Appeal [2015] 3 MLRA 717, Alau Baru v. Lee Ling Timber Sdn Bhd & Ors [2015] MLRAU 57.

The word 'in accordance to law' was discussed in S Kulaisingam & Anor v. Commissioner of Lands, Federal Territory & Ors [1981] 1 MLRA 184 followed in HCt in Bukit Kiara Resort Bhd v. Dato Bandar Kuala Lumpur [2011] 5 MLRH 892

The application of Art. 13 and ss. 5(3) and (4) of the Sarawak Land Code can be seen in the CA in Bato Bagi & Ors v. Government Of The State Of Sarawak [2011] 1 MLRA 389 and the HCt in Sangka Chuka & Ors v. Pentadbir Tanah Daerah Mersing Johor & Ors [2014] MLRHU 424.

Art 13 was applied in the HCt in Ngo Ong Chung & ors v. Pengarah Tanah dan Galian Perak Darul Ridzuan [2013] 6 MLRH 191 (reducing the tenure of land from freehold to leasehold), CA in Saratogoa Sdn Bhd v. Pentadbir Tanah Johor Bahru [2013] 5 MLRA 154 (forfeiture of land), CA in Ng Chin Siu & Sons Rubber Estate Sdn Bhd v. Pentadbir Tanah Hilir Perak, Jabatan Ketua Pengarah Tanah & Galian, Negeri Perak [2013] MLRAU 180 following Pow Hing & Anor v. Registrar Of Titles, Malacca [1980] 1 MLRA 57 (s 226(3) of the CA 1965), Md Mustaffa Md Sheriff v. RHB Bank Berhad [2011] 3 MLRA 69, CA (foreclosure), Syarikat Tungaring Kilang Papan (S) Sdn Bhd v. Director Of Forestry & Anor [2014] 2 MLRA 487 CA (expiry of land license), FCt in Kijal Resort Sdn Bhd v. Pentadbir Tanah Kemaman & Anor [2015] 1 MLRA 255; FCt in Tunku Yaacob Holdings Sdn Bhd v. Pentadbir Tanah Kedah & Ors [2015] 1 MLRA 355 and Ishmael Lim Abdullah v. Pesuruhjaya Tanah Persekutuan & Anor [2014] 4 MLRA 652 [CA], (acquisition of land), FCt in Mohd Khir Toyo v. PP [2015] 6 MLRA 1 (s 36(1) read with s 56 and s 2 of the Anti-Corruption Act 1997.)

The term 'Save in accordance with law' was discussed in S Kulaisingam & Anor v. Commissioner of Lands, Federal Territory & Ors [1981] 1 MLRA 184, FC, Philip Hoalim Jr & Anor v. State Commissioner, Penang [1976] 1 MLRA 668, PC, Arumugam Pillai v. Government Of Malaysia [1975] 1 MLRA 348, FC, Pengarah Tanah Dan Galian, Wilayah Persekutuan v. Sri Lempah Enterprise Sdn Bhd [1978] 1 MLRA 132, FC, Hock Huat Chan Sdn Bhd v. Assan Bin Mohammad & Ors [2008] 1 MLRH 634 where the High Court gave a wide interpretation of the word 'law'.

On the application of Art 13, please refer to Tekali Prospecting Sdn Bhd v. Tenaga Nasional Bhd & Anor [2001] 6 MLRH 126, the Court of Appeal in Tenaga Nasional Bhd v. Tekali Prospecting Sdn Bhd [2002] 1 MLRA 351, CA, per Gopal Sri Ram JCA, per Gopal Sri Ram JCA (dissenting) in Ng Kim Moi (P) & Ors v. Pentadbir Tanah Daerah, Seremban, Negeri Sembilan Darul Khusus (Negeri Sembilan Township Sdn Bhd & Anor, Proposed Intervenors) [2004] 1 MLRA 467, CA. See also Tan Sri Dato' Tajuddin Ramli v. Pengurusan Danaharta Nasional Bhd & Ors [2002] 1 MLRH 281, Mohamad Khalid Bin Farzalur Rahaman & Anor v. Citibank Bhd & Anor [2000] 1 MLRH 223, the Court of Appeal in Public Prosecutor v. Tan Lee Kok [1998] 1 MLRA 53, K Danapalasingam K Krisnan v. Majlis Perbandaran Petaling Jaya Selangor Darul Ehsan [2005] 2 MLRH 13, Majlis Perbandaran Pulau Pinang v. Syed Ahmed A/L MM Gouse Mohamed [2006] 2 MLRA 548, CA, Raja Singam A/L Velu lwn. Affin-ACF Finance Bhd Dan Lain-Lain [2007] 2 MLRH 578; Chong Chung Moi @ Christine Chong v. Government Of The State Of Sabah & Ors [2007] 6 MLRH 730; Ong See Teong & Anor v. Tenaga Nasional Bhd [2009] 1 MLRA 453. See also Jitender Singh A/L Pagar Singh & Ors v. Pentabdir Tanah Wilayah Persekutuan [2012] 4 MLRA 33, Tan Yen Foon v. Pentadbir Tanah Wilayah Persekutuan Kuala Lumpur [2007] 3 MLRH 705, Sakuragawa Pump (S) Pte Ltd v. Perkapalan Mesra Sdn Bhd [2007] 5 MLRH 420, Abdul Aziz bin Mohamed Ginan & Ors v. Datuk Bandar Kuala Lumpur [2007] 3 MLRH 89.

Majlis Perbandaran Pulau Pinang v. Syed Ahmed A/L MM Gouse Mohamed [2006] 2 MLRA 548 . See also Haji Jaafar Bin Haji Hashim & Ors v. Rohani Bte Ab Latip [2006] 3 MLRH 202 and Bato Bagi and Others v. Government Of The State Of Sarawak [2008] 2 MLRH 160.

Can Art 13 be applied against an individual? See CA in Koperasi Doktor Malaysia Berhad v. Dr Rajamohan Annamalai & Ors [2014] 3 MLRA 284 affirming FC in Beatrice A/P Fernandez v. Sistem Penerbangan Malaysia & Ors [2005] 1 MLRA 320; [2005] 1 MELR 1.

On the general application of Art 13(1) see HCt Mohd Adzlan Hj Zainal & Yang Lain lwn. Pegawai Penerima Syarikat Cosmopro Planners Sdn Bhd & Yang Lain Dan Satu Kes Yang Lain [2015] 4 MLRH 291, Bandar Utama City Corporation Sdn Bhd & Anor v. Pentadbir Tanah dan Daerah Petaling & Ors [2014] MLRHU 463

On Art 13(1) and the award of compensation under the Land Acquisition Act 1960, please refer to CA in Salak Land Development Sdn Bhd v. Pentadbir Tanah Kuala Langat & Ors [2015] 3 MLRA 372, CA in Exxonmobil Malaysia Sdn Bhd v. Pentadbir Tanah Daerah Petaling [2015] 6 MLRA 740, the HCt decision of See Ming Hoi v. Asmawi Kasbi Pentadir Tanah Daerah Kuala Langat & Ors [2014] MLRHU 429, HCt in Lim Goo Kia v. Pentadbir Tanah Daerah Kota Tingi & Ors and Another Appeal [2014] MLRHU 568, Tan Suat Bee lwn. Pentadbir Tanah Daerah Johor Bahru [2013] MLRHU 1079, Che Som Che Mat v. Pentadbir Tanah Daerah Kerian [2013] 5 MLRH 32, Victory Investment Company Sdn Bhd v. Pentadbir Tanah Daerah, Johor Bahru & Anor [2012] MLRHU 1573, TR Nyutan Jami & Ors v. Lembaga Pembangunan Dan Lindungan Tanah (Land Custody and Development Authority) & Ors [2012] MLRHU 1844, Projek Lintasan Kota Sdn Bhd v. Wisma Denmark Sdn Bhd & Anor [2012] MLRHU 1663, Ambank (M) Bhd lwn. Pentadbir Tanah Gombak [2012] MLRHU 1770, Luking Uding & Ors v. Superintendent Of Lands And Surveys Kota Samarahan Division & Ors [2011] 1 MLRH 376, Magnasar Sdn Bhd lwn. Kerajaan Negeri Perak dan Lain-Lain [2011] 13 MLRH 511, Ee Chong Pang & Ors v. The Land Administrator Of The District Of Alor Gajah & Anor [2013] 2 MLRA 307, Ng Kim Moi (P) & Ors v. Pentadbir Tanah Daerah, Seremban, Negeri Sembilan Darul Khusus (Negeri Sembilan Township Sdn Bhd & Anor, Proposed Intervenors) [2004] 1 MLRA 467 (distinguished) and CA in Ng Chin Siu & Sons Rubber Estate Sdn Bhd v. Pentadbir Tanah Hilir Perak, Jabatan Ketua Pengarah Tanah & Galian, Negeri Perak [2013] MLRAU 180.
On the continued occupation of the portion of the land by the defendant from 2009 and Art 13, please see Master Pyrodor Sdn Bhd v. Tai Thong Flower Nursery Sdn Bhd [2013] MLRHU 450

On Anti-Money Laundering, Anti-Terrorism Financing And Proceeds of Unlawful Activities Act 2001 and Art 13 amongst other, please see HCt in PP v. Thong Kian Oon & Ors [2014] 2 MLRH 172 and PP v. Syarikart OL Multi Trading & Anor [2015] MLRHU 421.

On Art 13(1) and the confiscation of property see Agus v. PP [2014] MLRHU 1239, Precious Concept Sdn Bhd lwn. CIMB Bank Berhad Dan Yang Lain [2014] MLRHU 757. However see the opposing decision in CA in Assan Mohamad & Ors v. Hock Huat Chan Sdn Bhd [2013] 4 MLRA 641

Low Poh Kim v. Pengarah Tanah Dan Galian Negeri Selangor & Ors [2014] 3 MLRH 309 discusses Art 13 and the indefesability of title under the National Land Code. The act of the Registrar in issuing the titles to the Defendant in respect of the Disputed Area was done arbitrarily with due regard to the interest of the Plaintiff and therefore in breach of Art 13(1). Associated Pan Malaysia Cement Sdn Bhd v. Westwood Development Sdn Bhd [2013] MLRHU 297. On the effect of an unlawfully acquired titled under S340(2)(c) of the NLC on Art 13(1), see the HCt cases of Uptown Properties Sdn Bhd v. Pentadbir Tanah Wilayah Persekutuan & Ors [2012] 2 MLRH 270 and Shayo (M) Sdn Bhd v. Nurlieda Sidek & Ors [2012] MLRHU 1208, CIMB Bank Berhad v. Ambank (M) Berhad & Ors [2015] 3 MLRH 313
On the Presence of a Registrar's Caveat and its effect on Art 13, see Motif Unik Sdn Bhd v. Khoo Ah Soon & Anor [2011] 8 MLRH 13
Acquisition of land under the Sarawak Land Code (CHAP 81) and Art 13 See Sebekai Plantations Sdn Bhd v. Superintendent Of Lands and Surveys, Bintulu [2012] 5 MLRH 234
On Art 13(1) and common property see JMB Silverpark Sdn Bhd v. Silverpark Sdn Bhd & Anor (Encls 1 & 6) [2012] MLRHU 1298.
On ss 148 and 151 of the Local Government Act 1976 and Art 13 please see HCt in Datuk Bandar Kuala Lumpur v. Ho Poh Sim [2015] 5 MLRH 724.

Whenever a competent legislature enacts a law in the exercise of any of its legislative powers, destroying or otherwise depriving a man of his property, the latter is precluded from questioning its reasonableness by invoking Art 13(1), however arbitrary the law might be. FCt in Mohd Khir Toyo v. PP [2015] 6 MLRA 1 affirming F Ct in Arumugam Pillai v. Government Of Malaysia [1975] 1 MLRA 348 See also CA in Mohd Khir Toyo lwn. Pendakwa Raya [2013] 5 MLRA 392

On the issue whether this court should use "international norms" embodied in the UNDRIP to interpret Arts 5 and 13 of the Fed Consti, see FCt in Bato Bagi & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Sarawak & Anor Appeal [2012] 1 MLRA 1.
On S340 NLC and Art 13, see CA in Majlis Mesyuarat Kerajaan Negeri Terengganu & Ors v. Darul Bayan Development Sdn Bhd [2015] 5 MLRA 522.

On s 3(1) Land Acquistition Act 1960 and Art 13(1) please see CA in Kuala Lumpur Kepong Berhad v. Pentadbir Tanah Jajahan Tanah Merah & Anor [2015] MLRAU 186 affirming Pemungut Hasil Tanah, Daerah Barat Daya, Pulau Pinang v. Ong Gaik Kee [1982] 1 MLRA 624, CA in Lembaga Pembangunan Dan Lindungan Tanah (Land Custody And Development Authority) & Ors v. Masa Nangkai & Ors [2015] MLRAU 55 applying Badiaddin Mohd Mahidin & Anor v. Arab Malaysian Finance Bhd [1998] 1 MLRA 183.
On the court's approach to the right of property, see obiter dictum of the CA in Superintendent Of Lands & Surveys, Samarahan Division & Anor v. Abas Naun & Ors [2014] MLRAU 157.
On the Joint Venture Agreement which violates Art 13 please see Masa Anak Nangkai & Ors v. Lembaga Pembangunan Dan Lindungan & Ors [2011] 3 MLRH 187.
Article 13(2)
Definition
'adequate compensation.'

The words 'adequate compensation' must be given their proper interpretation. A discussion of this can be seen in the CA in Jais Chee & Ors v. Superintendent of Lands & Surveys Kuching Division, Kuching [2014] 4 MLRA 48 and the FCt in Superintendent Of Lands and Surveys, Samarahan Division & Anor v. Abas Naun & Ors and Anor Appeal [2015] 1 MLRA 27. See also the High Court decision in Bato Bagi and Others v. Government Of The State Of Sarawak [2008] 2 MLRH 160 and Kerajaan Negeri Selangor & Ors v. Sagong Bin Tasi & Ors [2005] 1 MLRA 819 on the deliberation of what amounts to 'adequate compensation.'
Application

Art 13(2) was applied to the Orang Asli in Adong Bin Kuwau & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Johor & Anor [1997] 3 MLRH 95. See also Nor Anak Nyawai & Ors v. Borneo Pulp Plantation Sdn Bhd & Ors [2001] 1 MLRH 304 and the CA case of Kerajaan Negeri Selangor & Ors v. Sagong Bin Tasi & Ors [2005] 1 MLRA 819 CA and Bato Bagi and Others v. Government Of The State Of Sarawak [2008] 2 MLRH 160, CA in Yebet Saman & Ors v. Foong Kwai Long & Ors [2014] MLRAU 494, FC in Bato Bagi & Ors v. Kerajaan Negeri Sarawak & Another Appeal [2012] 1 MLRA 1.

On the adequacy of compensation please refer to the CA case of Singapore Para Rubber Estate Ltd v. Pentadbir Tanah Daerah Rembau, Negeri Sembilan [2007] 2 MLRA 206 as well as the cases of Ting King Yii @ Ting King Yu & Ors v. Minister For Resource Planning & Anor [1993] 5 MLRH 1 and Pemungut Hasil Tanah, Daerah Barat Daya, Pulau Pinang v. Ong Gaik Kee [1982] 1 MLRA 624).

On Art 13(2) and the Land Acquisition Act 1960, please refer to the CA in Ismail Bakar & Ors v. Director Of Lands and Mines, Kedah Darul Aman [2010] 2 MLRA 684 and Jitender Singh A/L Pagar Singh & Ors v. Pentabdir Tanah Wilayah Persekutuan [2012] 4 MLRA 33
Please see CA in Jason Chan Huan Seng & Ors v. PP [2014] 6 MLRA 669 on the effect of an order under the Dangerous Drugs (Forfeiture of Property) Act 1988 on Art 13(2).
On the NLC and Art 13(2) please refer to the CA case in Superintendent Of Lands and Surveys, Bintulu Division v. Derawan Sdn Bhd & Ors And Anor Appeal [2014] 6 MLRA 603.

For the effect of s43 of the Co-operative Societies Act 1948 (Revised - 1983) on Art 13(2) please refer to the discussion by the CA in Koperasi Keretapi Berhad v. Menteri Kewangan Malaysia & Ors [2013] 4 MLRA 143. See also HCt in Jeno Jo & Anor v. The State Government Of Sarawak [2012] MLRHU 1816.

SECTION.p: (1) Subject to the provisions of this Part, the following persons are citizens by operation of law, that is to say:

blockquote.p: (a) every person born before Malaysia Day who is a citizen of the Federation by virtue of the provisions contained in Part I of the Second Schedule; and
(b) every person born on or after Malaysia Day, and having any of the qualifications specified in Part II of the Second Schedule.
(c) [Repealed].

SECTION.p: (2) [Repealed].
(3) [Repealed].

NOTE.p: On the rights of Orang Asli as citizens, please see the CA decisions in Yang Dipertua Majlis Daerah Gua Musang v. Pedik Busu & Ors [2014] 3 MLRA 505 and Director Of Forest, Sarawak & Anor v. TR Sandah Tabau & Ors [2014] 2 MLRA 186 affirming CA in Superintendent Of Lands & Surveys, Bintulu v. Nor Anak Nyawai & Ors And Another Appeal [2005] 1 MLRA 580 as well as FC in Superintendent Of Land & Surveys Miri Division & Anor v. Madeli Salleh [2007] 2 MLRA 390

p.i: 1. The present Article was inserted by Act 26/1963, section 23, in force from 16-09-1963, but Clauses (1)(c), (2) and (3), which are reproduced below, were repealed by Act 59/1966, section 2, in force from 09-08-1965:
"(1) (c) every citizen of Singapore.

(2) Subject to the provisions of this Part, provision with respect to citizenship of Singapore may be made by the constitution of that State, and may be amended by laws passed by the Legislature of that State and approved by Act of Parliament.

(3) Citizenship of Singapore shall not be severable from citizenship of the Federation, but a Singapore citizen by the loss of either shall lose the other also (subject to the provision made by this Part for the enrolment of a Singapore citizen as a citizen who is not a Singapore citizen).".
2. The earlier Article, as it stood at the date of repeal, read as follows:
"14. (1) Subject to the following provisions of this Article, the following persons are citizens by operation of law, that is to say:

(a) every person who, immediately before Merdeka Day, was citizen of the Federation by virtue of any of the provisions of the Federation of Malaya Agreement 1948, whether by operation of law or otherwise;
(b) every person born within the Federation on or after Merdeka Day;

(c) every person born outside the Federation on or after Merdeka Day whose father is a citizen at the time of the birth and either was born within the Federation or is at the time of the birth in service under the Government of the Federation or of a State;

(d) every person born outside the Federation on or after Merdeka Day whose father is a citizen at the time of the birth, if the birth is registered at a Malayan Consulate or, in the case of any such person born within any prescribed territory, with the Federal Government, within one year of its accurrence, or within such longer period as the Federal Government may in any particular case allow.

For the purposes of paragraph (d) of this Clause "prescribed territory" means Singapore, Sarawak, Brunei or North Borneo, or any such other territory as the Yang di-Pertuan Agong may by order prescribe for those purposes.
(2) A person is not a citizen by virtue of paragraph (b) of Clause (1) if, at the time of his birth-
(a) his father, not being a citizen of the Federation, possessed such immunity from suit and legal process as is accorded to an envoy of a sovereign power credited to the Yang di-Pertuan Agong; or
(b) in the case of a birth occurring in a place under occupation by the enemy, his father was an enemy alien; or
(c) neither of his parents was a citizen of the Federation and neither of them was a permanent resident therein:
Provided that paragraph (c) of this Clause does not apply-
(i) to any person born within the Federation before the date on which section 2 of the Constitution (Amendment) Act 1962 come into force;
(ii) to any person if, as a result of the application of that paragraph, he would not be a citizen of any country.

(3) For the purposes of this Article a person born on board a registered ship or aircraft shall be deemed to have been born in the place in which the ship or aircraft was registered, and a person born on board an unregistered ship or aircraft of the Government of any country shall be deemed to have been born in that country.

(4) For the purposes of paragraph (c) of Clause (2) a person shall be treated as having been at any time a permanent resident in the Federation if, but only if, he was then resident in the Federation and either-
(a) he then had permission, granted without limit of time under any Federal law, to reside there; or
(b) it is certified by the Federal Government that he is to be treated for the purposes of the said paragraph (c) as a permanent resident in the Federation.

(5) A certificate of the Federal Government that a person is or was excluded from the application of paragraph (c) of Clause (2) by paragraph (ii) of the proviso to that Clause shall be conclusive evidence of the matter certified.".

NOTE.p: On the discussion and application of Art 14(1) please refer to the cas of Haja Mohideen Bin MK Abdul Rahman & Ors v. Menteri Dalam Negeri & Others [2007] 2 MLRH 87.
Application:

On whether an Adoption Order granted would suffice to qualify an adoptive child as citizen by operation of law under Art 14(1)(b) of the FC, please refer to the HCt case of Foo Toon Aik v. Ketua Pendaftar Kelahiran & Kematian, Malaysia [2012] 2 MLRH 548

b.ST: Citizenship by registration (wives and children of citizens).

SECTION.p: (1) Subject to Article 18, any married woman whose husband is a citizen is entitled, upon making application to the Federal Government, to be registered as a citizen if the marriage was subsisting and the husband a citizen at the beginning of October 1962, or if she satisfies the Federal Government-

blockquote.p: (a) that she has resided in the Federation throughout the two years preceding the date of the application and intends to do so permanently; and
(b) that she is of good character.

SECTION.p: (2) Subject to Article 18, the Federal Government may cause any person under the age of twenty-one years of whose parents one at least is (or was at death) a citizen to be registered as a citizen upon application made to the Federal Government by his parent or guardian.

(3) Subject to Article 18, a person under the age of twenty-one years who was born before the beginning of October 1962, and whose father is (or was at his death) a citizen and was also a citizen at the beginning of that month (if then alive), is entitled upon application made to the Federal Government by his parentor guardian, to be registered as a citizen if the Federal Government is satisfied that he is ordinarily resident in the Federation and is of good character.
(4) For the purposes of Clause (1) residence before Malaysia Day in the territories comprised in the States of Sabah and Sarawak shall be treated as residence in the Federation.

(5) The reference in Clause (1) to a married woman is a reference to a woman whose marriage has been registered in accordance with any written law in force in the Federation, including any such law in force before Merdeka Day, or with any written law in force before Malaysia Day in the territories comprised in the States of Sabah and Sarawak:

Provided that this Clause shall not apply where the woman applies to be registered as a citizen before the beginning of September 1965, or such later date as may be fixed by order of the Yang di-Pertuan Agong, and is at the date of the application ordinarily resident in the States of Sabah and Sarawak.
(6) [Repealed].

p.i: 1. The present Article was inserted by Act 26/1963, section 25, in force from 16-09-1963. Act 59/1966, section 2, in force from 09-08-1965, amended it-
(a) by repealing Clause (6) which read as follows:
"(6) In Clause (1) the words "outside Singapore" shall not have effect in the case of a woman whose husband is a citizen by naturalization under Clause (2) of Article 19.";
(b) by deleting the references to Singapore and Singapore citizens in Clauses (1) to (5).

NOTE.p: Clause (1)
Is a non-citizen wife of a citizen entitled to enter or remain in Malaysia? Please see Re Meenal W/O Muniyandi [1979] 1 MLRH 369 on the court's deliberation.

p.i: Clause (3): See 2nd Sch. Pt. III, section 18.

NOTE.p: Clause (3)
For a discussion on the application of this Art, please refer to the case of Tan Keat Seng Kitson v. Kerajaan Malaysia [1995] 4 MLRH 116.

p.i: 2. The original Article as it stood on Merdeka Day read as follows:
"15. (1) Subject to Article 18, any woman who is married to a citizen is entitled, upon making application to the registering authority, to be registered as a citizen.

(2) Subject to Article 18, any person under the age of twenty- one years whose father is a citizen or, if deceased, was a citizen at the time of his death, is entitled, upon application made to the registration authority by his parent or guardian, to be registered as a citizen if that authority is satisfied that he is ordinarily resident in the Federation and is of good character.

(3) The reference in this Article to a woman who is married is a reference to a woman whose marriage has been registered in accordance with any written law in force in the Federation including any such law in force before Merdeka Day.".

Clauses (1) and (2) amended by Act 10/1960, section 2, in force from 01-12-1960, by substituting "Federal Government" for "registration authority" and "the Federal Government" for "that authority". These two Clauses as substituted by Act 14/1962, section 3, in force from 01-10-1962, read as follows:

"15. (1) Subject to Article 18, any woman who is married to a citizen is entitled, upon making application to the Federal Government, to be registered as a citizen if she satisfied the Federal Government-
(a) that she has resided continuously in the Federation for a period of not less than two years immediately preceding the date of the application;
(b) that she intends to reside permanently therein; and
(c) that she is of good character.

(2) Subject to Article 18, the Federal Government may cause any person under the age of twenty-one years, being the child of any citizen, to be registered as a citizen upon application made to the Federal Government by his parent or guardian.".
The words "State of Sabah and Sarawak" substituted for "Borneo States" by Act A514, section 19, in force from 27-08-1976.
Clauses (3) to (6): See note on previous page.

NOTE.p: The word 'Ordinarily resident' though not defined in the Constitution was considered by the Privy Council in the case of Sifton v. Sifton [1938] AC 656, [1938] 3 All ER 435.

SECTION.p: Special power to register children.
Subject to Article 18, the Federal Government may, in such special circumstances as it thinks fit, cause any person under the age of twenty-one years to be registered as a citizen.

p.i: Added by Act 14/1962, section 4, in force from 01-10-1962.

b.ST: Citizenship by registration (persons born in the Federation before Merdeka Day).

SECTION.p: Subject to Article 18, any person of or over the age of eighteen years who was born in the Federation before Merdeka Day is entitled, upon making application to the Federal Government, to be registered as a citizen if he satisfies the Federal Government-

blockquote.p: (a) that he has resided in the Federation during the seven years immediately preceding the date of the application, for periods amounting in the aggregate to not less than five years;
(b) that he intends to do so permanently;
(c) that he is of good character; and
(d) that he has an elementary knowledge of the Malay language.

p.i: 1. Act 10/1960, paragraphs 2(a) and (b), in force from 01-12-1960, subsitituted the words "Federal Government" fo "registration authority" and "that authority".
2. Act 25/1963, section 8, in force from 29-08-1963, deleted the words " except where the application is made within one year after Merdeka Day, " which appeared at the commencement of paragraph (d).
3. Act 26/1963, subsection 29(1), in force from 16-09-1963-
(a) inserted the words "outside Singapore" after "Federation" in paragraph (a). These words were subsequently repealed by Act 59/1966, section 2, in force from 09-08-1965;
(b) substituted the words "to do so permanently" for "to reside permanently therein" in paragraph (b).

NOTE.p: General Note

Please refer to the cases of Kung Aik v. Public Prosecutor [1970] 1 MLRH 510 and the HCt case of Kolandavaloo Ramasamy v. Menteri Dalam Negeri & Ors [2014] MLRHU 368 on the discussion of this Article.

b.ST: Citizenship by registration (persons resident in States of Sabah and Sarawak on Malaysia Day).

SECTION.p: Subject to Article 18, any person of or over the age of eighteen years who is on Malaysia Day ordinarily resident in the State of Sabah or Sarawak is entitled, upon making application to the Federal Government before September 1971, to be registered as a citizen if he satisfies the Federal Government-

blockquote.p: (a) that he has resided before Malaysia Day in the territories comprised in those States and after Malaysia Day in the Federation for periods which amount in the aggregate to not less than seven years in the ten years immediately preceding the date of the application, and which include the twelve months immediately preceding that date;
(b) that he intends to reside permanently in the Federation;
(c) that he is of good character; and

(d) except where the application is made before September 1965, and the applicant has attained the age of forty-five years at the date of the application, that he has a sufficient knowledge of the Malay language or the English language or, in the case of an applicant ordinarily resident in Sarawak, the Malay language, the English language or any native language in current use in Sarawak.

p.i: 1. Added by Act 26/1963, section 26, in force from 16-09-1963. Act 59/1966, section 2, in force from 09-08-1965, deleted the words "outside Singapore" which appeared in paragraphs (a) and (b) after "Federation". The words "the State of Sabah or Sarawak" substituted for "a Borneo State" by Act A514, section 19, in force from 27-08-1976.

NOTE.p: General Note:

Preferential treatment as regards alienation of land by the State to the natives of Sabah and Sarawak is also stipulated in Art 16A(5) of the Fed Consti. HCt in Pendor Banger & Ors v. Ketua Pengarah Jabatan Alam Sekitar & Ors [2011] 7 MLRH 877

SECTION.p: [Repealed].

p.i: 1. The words "Federal Government" were substituted for the words "registration authority" by Act 10/1960, paragraph 2(a), in force from 01-12-1960.
